title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Excepting on the Cheviot hills, coal is foundover the greater part of Northumberland,especially in the lower district; but thefinest kind, which alone is raised for exportation, and goes under the name ofNewcastle coals, is confined to a districtaround that town, called the Coal districtor Coal Measures.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: The Cheviot sheep area peculiar and very beautiful breed, rearedon the pastoral district round Cheviot.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: The shsep are ofthree kinds, the Cheviot, the heath, andthe longwoolled.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: The Cheviot hills,though barren and moorish on the top, areon the whole remarkably fertile, presentinga uniform sheet of green sward, and affording excellent pasturage for sheep, to whichpurpose they are entirely devoted.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Cheviot is elevated 2658 feet above thelevel of the sea ; Hedge Hope hill, 2347 ;Simonside hill, 1407; Alnwick moor, 808;and Blackheddon, near Stamfordham, 646.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: The mountains around Cheviot are themost valuable of these high districts,being in general fine green hills, throwninto a great variety of forms, and inclosing many deep, narrow, and sequestered glens, some of which, towards thetop of the mountain, from their magnitude,the solitude which reigns in them, and thedark and craggy appearance of the rocks,from which the waters issue, have an air ofgreat wildness and sublimity.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: In the northern part of the county, betweenWooller and Alnwick, these mountains approach very near to the coast, the top ofCheviot, which is the highest of them, notbeing distant from it above 18 miles; butfrom this point they extend westwardsinto the interior, leaving along the coasta much greater breadth of low or of upland land, both on the north and south.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: The lofty range of theCheviot and other mountains divides it onthe west and north-west from Cumberland,and from Roxburghshire in Scotland ; andon the nerth it is divided from Berwickshire by the river Tweed, if we include inthis description the small triangular district of Islandshire, between Holy Islandand Coldstream, which forms the mostnorthern land of the kingdom, but, in respect of civil jurisdiction, belongs to thecounty of Durham.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: 1 1 is supposed that the black-facedspecies is the best adapted to the climate ;as the Cheviot breed, being of a more delicate nature, die very frequently from thecold, when newly produced.
